author: Sam Sherwood
title: Young father pleads guilty to manslaughter for shaking toddler
text:
Young father pleads guilty to manslaughter for shaking toddler SAM SHERWOOD Last updated 16:09, February 3 2017 MARTIN VAN BEYNEN/FAIRFAX NZ 
The man said he felt overwhelmed at being a father. 
A young father has admitted forcefully shaking his crying son, killing the toddler. 
The man, who was granted interim name suppression, pleaded guilty to manslaughter in the Christchurch High Court on Friday before Judge Rachel Dunningham. The suppression order extends to the man's child and other identifying details. 
The offender, who was originally charged with murder over the death, said he felt overwhelmed at being a father and having to care for his son as often as he did. 
The child had been crying and not settling on the night of the shaking. The man said he picked his son up and shook him with sufficient force to cause head injuries that ultimately led to his death. 
He said he immediately regretted the action and took his son to hospital after alerting a relative in the house. 
The toddler died later in hospital of severe head trauma which disrupted the blood supply to his brain. He had retinal haemorrhages causing blindness. 
Experts confirmed the injuries sustained by the child were consistent with him being shaken. It was difficult to quantify the precise level of force required to cause the injuries received. However, it was commonly accepted it was more than normal handling or play between an adult and child. 
The man was spoken to a number of times by police but initially maintained he knew nothing about the injuries and he had never assaulted his son. 
The judge issued the man a first strike warning. He is due to be sentenced in March.
